text: Adoration to the Highest Self (Paramâtman)!

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 1. G anaka Vaideha (the king of the Videhas) sacrificed with a sacrifice at which many presents were offered to the priests of (the A s vamedha). Brâhma n as of the Kurus and the Pâ ñ kâlas had come thither, and G anaka Vaideha wished to know, which of those Brâhma n as was the best read. So he enclosed a thousand cows, and ten pâdas (of gold) 2 were fastened to each pair of horns.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 2. And G anaka spoke to them: 'Ye venerable Brâhma n as, he who among you is the wisest, let him drive away these cows.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Then those Brâhma n as durst not, but Yâ g ñ avalkya said to his pupil: 'Drive them away, my dear.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: He replied: 'O glory of the Sâman 3 ' and drove them away.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: The Brâhma n as became angry and said: 'How could he call himself the wisest among us?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Now there was A s vala, the Hot ri priest of G anaka Vaideha. He asked him: 'Are you indeed the

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: wisest among us, O Yâ g ñ avalkya?' He replied: 'I bow before the wisest (the best knower of Brahman), but I wish indeed to have these cows.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Then A s vala, the Hot ri priest, undertook to question him.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 1. 'Yâ g ñ avalkya, he said, 'everything here (connected with the sacrifice) is reached by death, everything is overcome by death. By what means then is the sacrificer freed beyond the reach of death?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Yâ g ñ avalkya said: 'By the Hot ri priest, who is Agni (fire), who is speech. For speech is the Hot ri of the sacrifice (or the sacrificer), and speech is Agni, and he is the Hot ri . This constitutes freedom, and perfect freedom (from death).'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 4. 'Yâ g ñ avalkya,' he said, 'everything here is reached by day and night, everything is overcome by day and night. By what means then is the sacrificer freed beyond the reach of day and night?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Yâ g ñ avalkya said: 'By the Adhvaryu priest, who is the eye, who is Âditya (the sun) 1 . For the eye is the Adhvaryu of the sacrifice, and the eye is the sun, and he is the Adhvaryu. This constitutes freedom, and perfect freedom.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 5. 'Yâ g ñ avalkya,' he said, 'everything here is reached by the waxing and waning of the moon, everything is overcome by the waxing and waning of the moon. By what means then is the sacrificer freed beyond the reach of the waxing and waning of the moon?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Yâ g ñ avalkya said: 'By the Udgât ri priest, who is Vâyu (the wind), who is the breath. For the

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: breath is the Udgât ri of the sacrifice, and the breath is the wind, and he is the Udgât ri . This constitutes freedom, and perfect freedom.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 6. 'Yâ g ñ avalkya,' he said, 'this sky is, as it were, without an ascent (staircase.) By what approach does the sacrificer approach the Svarga world?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Yâ g ñ avalkya said: 'By the Brahman priest, who is the mind (manas), who is the moon. For the mind is the Brahman of the sacrifice, and the mind is the moon, and he is the Brahman. This constitutes freedom, and perfect freedom. These are the complete deliverances (from death).'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: Next follow the achievements.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 7. 'Yâ g ñ avalkya,' he said, 'how many Ri k verses will the Hot ri priest employ to-day at this sacrifice?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 'Three,' replied Yâ g ñ avalkya.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 'And what are these three?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 'Those which are called Puronuvâkyâ, Yâ g yâ, and, thirdly, S asyâ 1 .'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 'What does he gain by them?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 'All whatsoever has breath.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 8. 'Yâ g ñ avalkya,' he said, 'how many oblations (âhuti) will the Adhvaryu priest employ to-day at this sacrifice?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 'Three,' replied Yâ g ñ avalkya.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 'And what are these three?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 'Those which, when offered, flame up; those which, when offered, make an excessive noise; and those which, when offered, sink down 2 .'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 'What does he gain by them?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 'By those which, when offered, flame up, he gains the Deva (god) world, for the Deva world flames up, as it were. By those which, when offered, make an excessive noise, he gains the Pit ri (father) world, for the Pit ri world is excessively (noisy) 1 . By those which, when offered, sink down, he gains the Manushya (man) world, for the Manushya world is, as it were, down below.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 9. 'Yâ g ñ avalkya,' he said, 'with how many deities does the Brahman priest on the right protect to-day this sacrifice?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 'By one,' replied Yâ g ñ avalkya.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 'And which is it?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 'The mind alone; for the mind is endless, and the Vi s vedevas are endless, and he thereby gains the endless world.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 10. 'Yâ g ñ avalkya,' he said, 'how many Stotriyâ hymns will the Udgât ri priest employ to-day at this sacrifice?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 'Three,' replied Yâ g ñ avalkya.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 'And what are these three?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 'Those which are called Puronuvâkyâ, Yâ g yâ, and, thirdly, S asyâ.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 'And what are these with regard to the body (adhyâtmam)?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 'The Puronuvâkyâ is Prâ n a (up-breathing), the Yâ g yâ the Apâ n a (down-breathing), the S asyâ the Vyâna (back-breathing).'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 'What does he gain by them?'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 'He gains the earth by the Puronuvâkyâ, the sky by the Yâ g yâ, heaven by the S asyâ.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: After that A s vala held his peace.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 121:1 Mâdhyandina text, p. 1067.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 121:2 Pala k aturbhâga h pâda h suvar n asya. Comm.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 121:3 One expects iti after uda g a, but Sâma s ravas is applied to Yâ g ñ avalkya, and not to the pupil. Yâ g ñ avalkya, as the commentator observes, was properly a teacher of the Ya g ur-veda, but as the pupil calls him Sâmasravas, he shows that Yâ g ñ avalkya knew all the four Vedas, because the Sâmans are taken from the Ri g-veda, and the Atharva-veda is contained in the other three Vedas. Regnaud, however, refers it to the pupil, and translates, 'Ô toi qui apprends le Sâma-veda.'

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 122:1 One expects âdityena k akshushâ, instead of k akshushâdityena, but see § 6.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 123:1 The Puronuvâkyâs are hymns employed before the actual sacrifice, the Yâ g yâs accompany the sacrifice, the S asyâs are used for the S astra. All three are called Stotriyâs.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 123:2 These oblations are explained as consisting of wood and oil, of flesh, and of milk and Soma. The first, when thrown on the p. 124 fire, flame up. The second, when thrown on the fire, make a loud hissing noise. The third, consisting of milk, Soma, &c., sink down into the earth.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
text: 124:1 On account of the cries of those who wish to be delivered out of it. Comm.

translator: Max Müller (Sacred Books of the East) — Public Domain
